section_title: To the Shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway Inc.
chunk_text: Our gain in net worth during 2009 was $21.8 billion, which increased the per-share book value of both our Class A and Class B stock by 19.8%. Over the last 45 years (that is, since present management took over) book value has grown from $19 to $84,487, a rate of 20.3% compounded annually.* Berkshire’s recent acquisition of Burlington Northern Santa Fe (BNSF) has added at least 65,000 shareholders to the 500,000 or so already on our books. It’s important to Charlie Munger, my long-time partner, and me that all of our owners understand Berkshire’s operations, goals, limitations and culture. In each annual report, consequently, we restate the economic principles that guide us. This year these principles appear on pages 89-94 and I urge all of you – but particularly our new shareholders – to read them. Berkshire has adhered to these principles for decades and will continue to do so long after I’m gone.
principle_statement: Berkshire has adhered to economic principles for decades and will continue to do so long after I’m gone.
contextual_summary: This chunk discusses Berkshire's significant gain in net worth during 2009 and the increase in per-share book value, emphasizing the importance of understanding the company's operations and principles. Buffett highlights the recent acquisition of BNSF and encourages shareholders, especially new ones, to read the economic principles that guide Berkshire's management. This reflects his commitment to transparency and long-term value creation.

chunk_text: Our metrics for evaluating our managerial performance are displayed on the facing page. From the start, Charlie and I have believed in having a rational and unbending standard for measuring what we have – or have not – accomplished. That keeps us from the temptation of seeing where the arrow of performance lands and then painting the bull’s eye around it. Selecting the S&P 500 as our bogey was an easy choice because our shareholders, at virtually no cost, can match its performance by holding an index fund. Why should they pay us for merely duplicating that result?
principle_statement: We believe in having a rational and unbending standard for measuring performance.
contextual_summary: This chunk outlines Buffett's approach to measuring managerial performance, emphasizing the importance of rational standards and the choice of the S&P 500 as a benchmark. He argues that shareholders can easily match the index's performance through index funds, highlighting the need for Berkshire to provide genuine value beyond mere duplication of market results. This reflects his commitment to accountability and transparency in performance evaluation.

chunk_text: A more difficult decision for us was how to measure the progress of Berkshire versus the S&P. There are good arguments for simply using the change in our stock price. Over an extended period of time, in fact, that is the best test. But year-to-year market prices can be extraordinarily erratic. Even evaluations covering as long as a decade can be greatly distorted by foolishly high or low prices at the beginning or end of the measurement period.
principle_statement: Year-to-year market prices can be extraordinarily erratic.
contextual_summary: This chunk discusses the challenges of measuring Berkshire's progress against the S&P 500, highlighting the potential distortions caused by market price fluctuations. Buffett acknowledges that while stock price changes are a valid measure over extended periods, they can be erratic year-to-year, emphasizing the need for a more stable metric for evaluation. This reflects his commitment to accurate performance assessment.

chunk_text: The ideal standard for measuring our yearly progress would be the change in Berkshire’s per-share intrinsic value. Alas, that value cannot be calculated with anything close to precision, so we instead use a crude proxy for it: per-share book value. Relying on this yardstick has its shortcomings, which we discuss on pages 92 and 93.
principle_statement: We use per-share book value as a proxy for intrinsic value.
contextual_summary: This chunk explains Buffett's preference for measuring Berkshire's progress through per-share intrinsic value, despite the challenges in calculating it precisely. He acknowledges the use of per-share book value as a proxy, while also noting its limitations. This reflects his commitment to transparency and the pursuit of accurate performance metrics.

chunk_text: Additionally, book value at most companies understates intrinsic value, and that is certainly the case at Berkshire. In aggregate, our businesses are worth considerably more than the values at which they are carried on our books. In our all-important insurance business, moreover, the difference is huge.
principle_statement: Book value understates intrinsic value at Berkshire.
contextual_summary: This chunk highlights the discrepancy between book value and intrinsic value at Berkshire, emphasizing that the company's businesses are worth significantly more than their recorded values. Buffett points out that this is particularly true for their insurance business, where the difference is substantial. This reflects his commitment to providing shareholders with a clear understanding of the company's true value.

chunk_text: Even so, Charlie and I believe that our book value – understated though it is – supplies the most useful tracking device for changes in intrinsic value. By this measurement, as the opening paragraph of this letter states, our book value since the start of fiscal 1965 has grown at a rate of 20.3% compounded annually.
principle_statement: Book value is the most useful tracking device for changes in intrinsic value.
contextual_summary: This chunk reiterates Buffett's belief that, despite its shortcomings, book value serves as the most effective measure for tracking changes in intrinsic value at Berkshire. He emphasizes that since fiscal 1965, the company's book value has grown at a compounded annual rate of 20.3%, highlighting the company's strong performance over the long term.

chunk_text: We should note that had we instead chosen market prices as our yardstick, Berkshire’s results would look better, showing gains since the start of fiscal 1965 of 22% compounded annually. Surprisingly, this modest difference in annual compounding rate leads to an 801,516% market-value gain for the entire 45-year period compared to the book-value gain of 434,057% (shown on page 2).
principle_statement: Market prices can show a better performance than book value.
contextual_summary: This chunk discusses the potential for Berkshire's results to appear more favorable if measured by market prices instead of book value, highlighting a significant difference in compounding rates over the 45-year period. Buffett notes that while market-value gains are impressive, the book-value gain remains substantial, emphasizing the importance of understanding both metrics in evaluating the company's performance.

chunk_text: Summed up, the table on page 2 conveys three messages, two positive and one hugely negative. First, we have never had any five-year period beginning with 1965-69 and ending with 2005-09 – and there have been 41 of these – during which our gain in book value did not exceed the S&P’s gain. Second, though we have lagged the S&P in some years that were positive for the market, we have consistently done better than the S&P in the eleven years during which it delivered negative results. In other words, our defense has been better than our offense, and that’s likely to continue.
principle_statement: Our gain in book value has consistently exceeded the S&P’s gain.
contextual_summary: This chunk summarizes key insights from the performance table, emphasizing that Berkshire's book value has consistently outperformed the S&P 500 over various five-year periods. Buffett highlights the company's strong defensive performance during market downturns, suggesting that this trend is likely to continue. This reflects his confidence in Berkshire's long-term resilience and value creation.

next_context: The big minus is that our performance advantage has shrunk dramatically as our size has grown, an unpleasant trend that is certain to continue.

chunk_text: Long ago, Charlie laid out his strongest ambition: “All I want to know is where I’m going to die, so I’ll never go there.” That bit of wisdom was inspired by Jacobi, the great Prussian mathematician, who counseled “Invert, always invert” as an aid to solving difficult problems. (I can report as well that this inversion approach works on a less lofty level: Sing a country song in reverse, and you will quickly recover your car, house and wife.)
contextual_summary: This chunk shares a humorous anecdote about Charlie Munger's philosophy on avoiding risky situations, illustrating his approach to decision-making. Buffett connects this wisdom to a broader principle of inverting problems to find solutions, showcasing the importance of strategic thinking in business. This reflects the collaborative mindset that drives Berkshire's success.
